journal-title-group.journal-title: Developmental dynamics : an official publication of the American Association of Anatomists

title-group.article-title: RNA helicase Mov10 is essential for gastrulation and CNS development

article-meta.aff: 1Neuroscience Program, University of Illinois-Urbana Champaign, Urbana, IL, 61801, USA
2Cell and Developmental Biology, University of Illinois-Urbana Champaign, Urbana, IL, 61801, USA
3High-Performance Biological Computing, Roy J. Carver Biotechnology Center, University of Illinois-Urbana Champaign, Urbana, IL, 61801, USA
4College of Medicine, University of Illinois-Urbana Champaign, Urbana, IL, 61801, USA

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Mov10 is an RNA helicase that modulates access of Argonaute 2 to microRNA recognition elements in mRNAs. We examined the role of Mov10 in Xenopus laevis development and show a critical role for Mov10 in gastrulation and in the development of the central nervous system.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Knockdown of maternal Mov10 in Xenopus embryos using a translation blocking morpholino led to defects in gastrulation and the development of notochord and paraxial mesoderm, and a failure to neurulate. RNA sequencing of the Mov10 knockdown embryos showed significant upregulation of many mRNAs when compared to controls at stage 10.5 (including those related to the cytoskeleton, adhesion, and extracellular matrix, which are involved in those morphogenetic processes). Additionally, the degradation of the miR-427 target mRNA, cyclin A1, was delayed in the Mov10 knockdowns. These defects suggest that Mov10â€™s role in miRNA-mediated regulation of the maternal to zygotic transition could lead to pleiotropic effects that cause the gastrulation defects. Additionally, the knockdown of zygotic Mov10 showed that it was necessary for normal head, eye and brain development in Xenopus consistent with a recent study in the mouse.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Mov10 is essential for gastrulation and normal CNS development.
